intro: Selaginella chrismari var. karwinskyana, commonly known as the Karwinsky's spikemoss, is a rare and ancient vascular plant belonging to the family Selaginellaceae. It is characterized by its slender, creeping stems that produce small, scale-like leaves arranged in whorls. This variety is native to specific regions in South America, particularly in Brazil, where it thrives in moist, shaded environments. Its reproductive structures include microsporangia and megasporangia, which are typical of its spore-producing life cycle. Due to its limited distribution and unique morphology, it is of interest to botanists studying evolutionary adaptations in early land plants.
